-LL6-nC1T4jN0JXRX8_8.name: Orientation schedule for families of new international students.

grid.narrative_description: Find all the details you need to make your plans and support your student as they make the move to RISD.
Discover how Experimental and Foundation Studies pushes first-year students to think in new ways and reach for surprising outcomes.

narrative_video.description: This is "First-year studios | A look at RISD's Experimental and Foundation Studies program" by RISD Media on Vimeo, the home for high quality videos...
narrative_video.html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fplayer.vimeo.com%2Fvideo%2F331075727%3Fapp_id%3D122963&dntp=1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fvimeo.com%2F331075727&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.vimeocdn.com%2Fvideo%2F776359267_1280.jpg&key=1f7aec2250b8486ba950a582d65e4cc9&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=vimeo" width="640" height="360" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>
narrative_video.title: First-year studios | A look at RISD's Experimental and Foundation Studies program

grid.large_button_text: Join us for Admitted Students Day!

grid.narrative_description: We're located in downtown Providence, the “Creative Capital” of Rhode Island. Small and urban, easy to work in and get around, it was built on a legacy of artistic experimentation that stretches back centuries.
Supported by a range of campus resources and opportunities, you’ll learn new ways of thinking and develop skills that allow you to create imaginative objects, products, experiences and works of art.

grid.quotation_citation: Rosanne Somerson BFA 76 Industrial Design, RISD's President
grid.quotation_text: “I am continually inspired by the long reach of RISD creativity, and the emerging multiplicity of voices pushing boundaries aside.”

grid.narrative_description: As independent thinkers and creative leaders, RISD alumni meet the complex needs of the 21st century by combining talent and vision with a knack for the unexpected.

narrative_video.description: With a RISD alumna, Rosanne Somerson 76 ID, serving as president for the first time, Rhode Island School of Design is producing a new series of video profiles to explore the various ways alumni artists and designers shape our world today and are poised to invent the future.
narrative_video.html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fplayer.vimeo.com%2Fvideo%2F142509371%3Fapp_id%3D122963&dntp=1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fvimeo.com%2F142509371&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.vimeocdn.com%2Fvideo%2F545285908_1280.jpg&key=1f7aec2250b8486ba950a582d65e4cc9&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=vimeo" width="640" height="360" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
narrative_video.title: RISD Alumni Make a Better Future

grid.narrative_description:
• Now available: New Student Orientation schedule, International Student Orientation schedule, orientation schedules for families of new students.
  • Brown classes begin (for BRDD students): September 4
  • RISD classes begin: September 5

RISD's Pre-Orientation Service Experience (POSE) is a great way to connect with Providence through community involvement and learn about long-term volunteer and leadership opportunities. This unique program empowers you to use art and design to make a difference at the local level.

grid.quotation_citation: Cass Sheedy BFA 19 Sculpture on POSE
grid.quotation_text: “What could be better than working with your hands for a good cause?”

grid.narrative_description: It's time to make new friends, settle into housing, learn the ropes of campus life and explore Providence. Your first year will get off to a great start with the useful information and insight you gain through our orientation programs.

The community you and your peers create in the studio will grow and thrive in the spaces on campus designed to help you feel a little more at home. Residence Life is here to help you navigate the transition to living at RISD.

grid.large_button_text: Find the information you need as a parent/guardian

grid.narrative_description: Amid the whirlwind of emotions that accompany moving in and acclimating to the steep incline of College Hill, 473 incoming first-year students (the Class of 2022) get acquainted with life at RISD.
grid.narrative_title: See what last year's orientation was like

grid.narrative_description: Keep up with the progress being made on RISD's current major building project: a new first-year residence hall designed by the firm of award-winning alumnus Nader Tehrani.

-Kf75EhAR5TZdkUf6LQd.description: Founded in 1995, Michael Maltzan Architecture in Los Angeles is committed to the idea that good design should benefit people of all socio-economic backgrounds. He has embraced commissions like the one for LA’s Inner-City Arts campus as readily as for Michael Ovitz’s Beverly Hills villa and is known for designing affordable housing complexes for the homeless, art centers and landscapes to stimulate and engage users. A 2012 recipient of the American Academy of Arts and Letters Award, Maltzan is the design architect for the Sixth Street Viaduct in LA, a new bridge and urban park that foresees a multimodal future for the city.
-Kf75EhAR5TZdkUf6LQd.name: Michael Maltzan
-Kf75EhAR5TZdkUf6LQd.title: architect

-Kf75Yf8cAedC7G297Gf.description: As co-owner of the NYC production studio Running Man, Ryan Cunningham does everything from consulting on scripts during pre-production and working on set during shooting to overseeing editing, visual effects, sound design, music, color correction and mastering. Cunningham got her start in film and television through an undergrad internship at WGBH, where she worked on live-action segments of the show Arthur. She currently spends most of her time producing for comedians including Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson (Broad City on Comedy Central) and Amy Schumer (Inside Amy Schumer on Comedy Central).
-Kf75Yf8cAedC7G297Gf.name: Ryan Cunningham
-Kf75Yf8cAedC7G297Gf.title: TV and film producer

-Kf75fAYWI8hfFlgKK_P.description: Fashion icon Nicole Miller recently won Philadelphia University’s 2013 Spirit of Design Award for outstanding contributions to the world of design and the inspiration she provides to students and young designers. Launched in 1982, her label now includes women’s apparel, handbags, footwear, jewelry, bridal wear and men’s sportswear. Miller credits RISD with inspiring her sense of freedom and creativity. She remains connected with the college as a visiting critic and mentor to RISD students, as well as a trustee.
-Kf75fAYWI8hfFlgKK_P.name: Nicole Miller
-Kf75fAYWI8hfFlgKK_P.title: industry leader

-Kf75qIMsaA0_EUO8Ufa.description: Providence-based artist Jungil Hong has been working with the nonprofit GAC since 2012 to raise money to build community housing in a rural Rwandan village. Hong was born in Korea, earned her BFA from RISD and also studied at the Penland School of Crafts, Haystack Mountain School of Crafts and Watershed Center for the Ceramic Arts. She has won numerous awards, including an RISCA Fellowship Merit Award, and has shown her work in such museums as MASS MoCA, the International Print Center in New York and the New Image Art Gallery in West Hollywood.
-Kf75qIMsaA0_EUO8Ufa.name: Jungil Hong
-Kf75qIMsaA0_EUO8Ufa.title: multimedia artist

-Kf764XGI_0CdO142Uuw.description: Within five years of graduation, video artist Ryan Trecartin had landed a trio of major awards, racking up more than $200,000 in art prizes. And it all started with his RISD senior degree project. Less than a decade later, the art critic for The New Yorker proclaimed him “the most consequential artist to have emerged since the 1980s,” while New York Times critic Roberta Smith predicts that he’s “bound for greatness.”
-Kf764XGI_0CdO142Uuw.name: Ryan Trecartin
-Kf764XGI_0CdO142Uuw.title: video artist

-Kf76KabEtOqPUN_kBug.description: Known for his audacious, often offbeat movies, director Gus Van Sant has built his success on a magical combination of ingenious writing, perceptive casting and a healthy obsession with detail. From Good Will Hunting to Finding Forrester to Milk, he has shown great range while maintaining an independent voice, as seen most recently in Promised Land, his 2013 feature about fracking.
-Kf76KabEtOqPUN_kBug.name: Gus Van Sant
-Kf76KabEtOqPUN_kBug.title: film director

-Kf76_VzzGfgYeddy8cj.description: After graduating in 2006, Theo Richardson, Charles Brill and Alex Williams repurposed their own last names to launch a NYC-based design studio called Rich Brilliant Willing. Since then they have made a distinctive mark in the design world by creating desirable products that are both disarmingly simple and totally user-oriented. In doing so, they have also earned broad critical acclaim, winning the ICFF Best New Designers Award in 2011 and several years ago making Forbes’ list of the top “30 Under 30” designers to watch.
-Kf76_VzzGfgYeddy8cj.name: Rich, Brilliant, Willing (Theo Richardson/Charles Brill/Alex Williams)
-Kf76_VzzGfgYeddy8cj.title: studio co-principals

-Kf76gx8Dfok3b6_HqxJ.description: Multimedia artist and 2006 MacArthur Award winner Josiah McElheny is fascinated with space, time and the notions of infinity and purity. While at RISD in the mid-1980s, he studied in Rome through the school’s European Honors Program and worked with master glassblowers such as Ronald Wilkins in London. McElheny currently lives and works in New York City, where he's represented by Andrea Rosen Gallery and has recently exhibited at White Cube in London and the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.
-Kf76gx8Dfok3b6_HqxJ.name: Josiah McElheny

related_links.link_title: Josiah McElheny at the Andrea Rosen Gallery

-Kf76gx8Dfok3b6_HqxJ.title: studio artist

-Kf76ngB-010QxjO6A3U.description: After graduation Jessica Walsh worked at Pentagram and Print magazine, while freelancing for AIGA, I.D. magazine, Technology Review and The New York Times, among others. Her work has won national recognition, with Computer Arts citing her as a Top Rising Star in Design and Forbes naming her in its annual “30 under 30” round-up of promising new creative talent. In 2012 renowned designer Stefan Sagmeister invited her to become a partner in his firm, which is now known as Sagmeister & Walsh. She also started her own agency, &Walsh, in 2019.
-Kf76ngB-010QxjO6A3U.name: Jessica Walsh
-Kf76ngB-010QxjO6A3U.title: studio co-principal

-Kf76xUPj0hvt-ixtt5g.description: Working out of her studio in Brooklyn, NY, Julia Rothman combines disparate interests into a career of her own making. She freelances as an illustrator and pattern designer, creating products, designs and branding for clients ranging from Anthropologie to Crate & Barrel, The New York Times, Urban Outfitters and Victoria’s Secret. In addition, Rothman runs the design studio Also with two RISD friends, and based on her lifelong love of books, writes a book blog and has published three book projects of her own: Drawn In, The Exquisite Book and Farm Anatomy.
-Kf76xUPj0hvt-ixtt5g.name: Julia Rothman
-Kf76xUPj0hvt-ixtt5g.title: author/designer/illustrator

-Kf772k2O034aesdpozW.description: For the past decade, Fairey has continued to create and exhibit politically outspoken fine artwork while also working in the commercial realm through his LA-based creative agency Studio Number One. A fine artist, graphic designer, commercial artist and entrepreneur, Fairey best known for his ubiquitous 2008 Hope poster of Barack Obama. His image of the president is in the permanent collection at the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery and led to a commission for the cover of TIME magazine. For the last decade, Fairey has also been working in the commercial realm through his LA-based creative agency Studio Number One.
-Kf772k2O034aesdpozW.name: Shepard Fairey
-Kf772k2O034aesdpozW.title: artist and activist

-Kf77Cj2que7I-Xos6d2.description: Author/illustrator Jarrett Krosoczka has been passionate about storytelling through words and pictures since he was a kid. He has written 20 published books, including the Lunch Lady series, which has won two Children’s Choice Book Awards and was featured on National Public Radio. His TED Talk, which chronicles his journey from boy to artist, has been viewed more than a half-million times, and his Punk Farm and Lunch Lady series are currently in development as feature films.
-Kf77Cj2que7I-Xos6d2.name: Jarrett Krosoczka
-Kf77Cj2que7I-Xos6d2.title: children’s book author/illustrator

-Kf77aV6TkU24zvRYLtt.description: Throughout her career, Andrea Valentini has focused on incorporating unconventional industrial materials into inventive designs for furniture, lighting, handbags, accessories, wearable art and interior applications. Her critically acclaimed Coosh egg chair has been recognized by the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and her work has been included in the museum’s popular triennial exhibitions. As she continues to develop innovative new products and design sensual interiors, Valentini remains committed to creating art for everyday living.
-Kf77aV6TkU24zvRYLtt.name: Andrea Valentini
-Kf77aV6TkU24zvRYLtt.title: product designer

-Kf77jEUsZFfjw348jco.description: When Alina Vadera first graduated, she thought about moving to New York—as many designers do. But she quickly reconsidered when she realized that her home country was where things were really happening in the world of architecture: “Construction is booming in India,” she says. So in 2011 Vadera returned to her home city of Delhi, worked for a time with Studio Lotus and then went on to create AVA Studio, her own multidisciplinary design practice. Her clients include the fashion designer Gaurav Gupta and the Indian fashion retailer Ogaan.
-Kf77jEUsZFfjw348jco.name: Alina Vadera
-Kf77jEUsZFfjw348jco.title: interior architect

-Kf77rhECkdxj3TxFu5P.description: Balancing a studio practice with her position as senior jewelry designer at FGX International, Tzu-Ju Chen creates work that incorporates artistic traditions from around the world. At FGX she designs products for labels such as No Boundary and Style & Co. and works closely with art directors, clients and overseas vendors. Chen draws inspiration from various cultures encountered during her travels — including her year in Rome as part of RISD’s European Honors Program. A subsequent Fulbright Fellowship in China further fueled her research into working with unorthodox materials.
-Kf77rhECkdxj3TxFu5P.name: Tzu-Ju Chen
-Kf77rhECkdxj3TxFu5P.title: jewelry designer

-Kf78BF8PJ0qlb5N5wmf.description: When Do Ho Suh first left Korea to study at RISD, he didn’t realize that the experience would inspire an ongoing body of work focused on questions of cultural and personal identity. Now he divides his time between New York, London and Seoul, creating profound site-specific installations that are in high demand throughout the world. Suh’s work is included in almost every major museum collection, from the Whitney, the Guggenheim and MoMA in New York City to the Tate Modern in London to Artsonje Center in Seoul and the Mori Art Museum in Tokyo.
-Kf78BF8PJ0qlb5N5wmf.name: Do Ho Suh

related_links.link_title: Do Ho Suh at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery

-Kf78BF8PJ0qlb5N5wmf.title: fine artist

-Kf78bznl5XmRYBbXGJH.description: Whether she's photographing Hollywood celebrities or taking her own fine art photos—often of children or animals—Jill Greenberg manages to focus on the iconic. Her use of light and color exaggerates the figure while reducing it to its essence, allowing her to capture raw emotion, along with the attention of increasing numbers of viewers. Currently based in New York, Greenberg brings her inimitable style to assignment work for clients such as GQ, HBO, Showtime, Universal Pictures and Wired, among many others.
-Kf78bznl5XmRYBbXGJH.name: Jill Greenberg
-Kf78bznl5XmRYBbXGJH.title: commercial + fine art photographer

-Kf78kU78Q3BUC_uREEF.description: Mural artist Jane Kim majored in Printmaking at RISD and says her education shaped how she works as an artist. In addition to honing technical art skills, she learned to ask herself why she makes what she does. After graduation, Kim pursued her love of nature by enrolling in the Science Illustration Program at California State University at Monterey Bay. She is currently working on a series of roadside murals in the American west depicting endangered species, such as the Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep, in order to draw attention to their plight.
-Kf78kU78Q3BUC_uREEF.name: Jane Kim
-Kf78kU78Q3BUC_uREEF.title: environmental artist

-Kf78tUD6R0JJbVN-09e.description: A recipient of the prestigious Baloise Prize given at Art Basel, Jim Drain makes fanciful multi-textured sculpture shown throughout the world, including in Utopia Muscle at Nathalie Karg Gallery in NYC (2017) and other solo shows at Prism Gallery in Los Angeles (2012), the De la Cruz Collection in Miami (2010), Blanton Museum in Austin (2009) and the Drantmann Gallery in Brussels (2004). As a visiting artist at RISD in 2014, he collaborated with students on developing a site-specific piece for the new US Embassy compound in Rabat, Morocco.
-Kf78tUD6R0JJbVN-09e.name: Jim Drain

related_links.link_title: Jim Drain at Nathalie Karg Gallery

-Kf78tUD6R0JJbVN-09e.title: Fine artist

-Kf79FsDHcdiRHMBcaSY.description: When Rachel Doriss first came to RISD, she was already head over heels in love with textiles and planned to open a small weaving studio in rural Vermont. But while studying both printed and woven techniques, she developed an itch to explore practical applications within the textiles industry. Once Doriss moved to NYC after graduation, she initially landed a job designing printed scarves at Echo before joining Mark Pollack [BFA 76/Textiles] at his namesake firm POLLACK, where she is now vice president and design director.
-Kf79FsDHcdiRHMBcaSY.name: Rachel Doriss

related_links.link_title: Rachel Doriss on Pollack & Associates' website

-Kf79FsDHcdiRHMBcaSY.title: textiles executive

-Kxj3Srof3IVeZ_p6Jox.description: Transforming their multidisciplinary talents into an avant-garde but accessible fashion label, Mike Eckhaus and Zoe Latta have earned a near continuous stream of praise since they released their first collection in 2011. Most recently Vogue called their Spring/Summer 2018 collection among “the best of New York Fashion Week” and the duo continues to turn heads with their unique collaborations and unconventional approach to collaborative design, business development and social media marketing.
-Kxj3Srof3IVeZ_p6Jox.name: Eckhaus Latta (Mike Eckhaus/Zoe Latta)
-Kxj3Srof3IVeZ_p6Jox.title: Apparel Designers

-Kxn1vZriG3dYPmOz_M9.description: After graduating from RISD, Rebecca Hannon moved to New York City and worked for five years as a goldsmith. Support from a Fulbright Fellowship enabled her to study at the Akademie der Bildenden Kuenste in Munich. Hannon’s work has been featured in solo shows in Montreal, Hudson, NY and Chicago and she currently teaches at Nova Scotia College of Arts & Design in Halifax.
-Kxn1vZriG3dYPmOz_M9.name: Rebecca Hannon
-Kxn1vZriG3dYPmOz_M9.title: Jewelry Designer

-Kxn5ScniJGy8TmNL9aa.description: An award-winning designer, Lindsay Degen is best known for her playful knitwear and fashions—for kids through Baby DEGEN and adults through her main line DEGEN. In 2013, shoes she designed in collaboration with Converse wound up gracing the feet of Rihanna and in the time since she's embarked on successful partnerships with Todd Selby, GERLAN, VPL and Victoria's Secret.
-Kxn5ScniJGy8TmNL9aa.name: Lindsay Degen
-Kxn5ScniJGy8TmNL9aa.title: Designer

-KxnB9LT3OV2w1htI7ZA.description: Represented by Ryan Lee Gallery in New York, Martine Gutierrez investigates identity are extending the scope of performance art. Her recent exhibitions have been featured at Flag Art Foundation in New York, Boston University, the CAM in Raleigh, NC and the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, where her work is also included in the permanent collection. “I think of my work as documentations of transformation and performance,” Gutierrez says. “While gender is undoubtedly always a question in my work, I don’t see it as a boundary.”
-KxnB9LT3OV2w1htI7ZA.name: Martine Gutierrez
-KxnB9LT3OV2w1htI7ZA.title: Fine Artist

-KxnypumAatWNid9bRFb.description: As demonstrated in the mid-career survey at the Whitney on view this winter, Laura Owens is expanding the limits of abstract painting. Over the course of her 20-year career, the Los Angeles-based painter has had solo exhibitions at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, Vienna Secession in Austria and Kunstmuseum in Bonn, Germany among others. Her work has also been featured in two Whitney biennials (2004 and 2014) and The Forever Now: Contemporary Painting in an Atemporal World at the Museum of Modern Art (2014).
-KxnypumAatWNid9bRFb.name: Laura Owens
-KxnypumAatWNid9bRFb.title: Fine Artist

-Kxo0lRlHfzaQZmAd1dN.description: An art director, designer and writer, Jon Key is a co-founder of Codify Art, a Brooklyn-based multidisciplinary artist collective whose mission is to create, produce, and showcase work that foregrounds the voices of people of color, highlighting women and queer people of color. He is also a co-principal (with Wael Morcos) of Morcos Key, a design collaboration. Key creates work centered on heritage, identity, and culture.
-Kxo0lRlHfzaQZmAd1dN.name: Jon Key
-Kxo0lRlHfzaQZmAd1dN.title: Designer, activist and Studio Co-Principal

-Kxo8kB1BTXROd2uY1hZ.description: A storytelling innovator, Brian Selznick is an award-winning author/illustrator with an unmistakable visual style. In books like Wonderstruck and The Marvels, the Brooklyn-based artist combines narrative prose with hundreds of pages of pencil drawings that convey stories without words. Selznick is perhaps best known for The Invention of Hugo Cabret, which was honored with a Caldecott Medal and adapted for the screen in Martin Scorcese’s Oscar-winning film Hugo. With a screenplay written by Selznick and directed by Todd Haynes, the movie adaptation of Wonderstruck premiered in October 2017.
-Kxo8kB1BTXROd2uY1hZ.name: Brian Selznick
-Kxo8kB1BTXROd2uY1hZ.title: Illustrator, writer and screenwriter

-KxoEPsfKa48TtxL9bC1.description: Calling herself “a devoted materialist” in a 2014 interview with BOMB magazine, Nicole Cherubini incorporates everything from glazed earthenware to terracotta, porcelain and MDF into her energetic sculptural forms. Her work has been featured in solo and group shows in Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Miami.
-KxoEPsfKa48TtxL9bC1.name: Nicole Cherubini
-KxoEPsfKa48TtxL9bC1.title: Fine Artist

-KyWV-Vby7XSvNLr_PX_.description: An Alaska native, Acacia Johnson captures in her photographs the vibrancy of life in the arctic. The recipient of a 2014–15 Fulbright Fellowship that brought her to the northern reaches of Canada, Johnson has had her work featured in the Canadian Embassy in Washington, DC, in National Geographic and Juxtapoz. Now a resident of Norway, she exhibits her photography internationally and works as a seasonal guide and lecturer for Quark Expeditions.
-KyWV-Vby7XSvNLr_PX_.name: Acacia Johnson
-KyWV-Vby7XSvNLr_PX_.title: Photographer

-KyXL8o_p1eI0tXiXnet.description: Tavares Strachan first caught the attention of the international art world in 2006 when he traveled to the Arctic to excavate a 4.5-ton block of ice, transport it back to his native Bahamas and display it in a solar-powered freezer. In the years since, he has exhibited at venues such as MIT's List Art Gallery, the Brooklyn Museum and Ron Feldman Fine Arts. In 2013 he represented the Bahamas in its inaugural pavilion at the 55th Venice Biennale.
-KyXL8o_p1eI0tXiXnet.name: Tavares Strachan

related_links.link_title: Tavares Strachan at Anthony Meier Gallery

-KyXL8o_p1eI0tXiXnet.title: Fine Artist

-L-bc4UNbA7OUg_h94y2.description: A senior designer at littleBits, Ryan Mather focuses on the physical design of future Bits. He has collaborated on the launch of the littleBits Education Code Kit and STEAM Student Set. Beyond his contributions to the company, he is currently working to develop a game called Flip Tales and occasionally consults for Anji Play, an early childhood development curriculum being developed in China by educator Cheng Xuequin.
-L-bc4UNbA7OUg_h94y2.name: Ryan Mather

-KejuUz4x73dSmIDFQvQ.description:
Prior to the beginning of the fall semester, new BRDD students will move into their first-year residence hall at RISD. They will attend a Dual Degree Orientation organized jointly by RISD and Brown and will then choose a specialized program to attend before the start of the general RISD and Brown orientations for all first-year students (programs listed below).

First-year BRDD students largely prioritize RISD Orientation as they will be residents at RISD. They are invited to participate in first-year group activities at Brown's general orientation and throughout the year. Additionally, students will participate in Brown’s First Reading Seminar Program and in Brown's first-year advising meeting.

Orientation program options
All first-year BRDD students must attend the Brown|RISD Dual Degree Orientation from Sunday, August 25, 2019 through Tuesday, August 27, 2019.

Then BRDD students must also enroll in one of the following programs as part of their Orientation experience:

  • Brown International Student Orientation (required of BRDD students on a visa)
  • Brown Third World Transition Program (TWTP)
  • RISD POSE
  • RISD Thrive

Space is limited in these programs and students must submit their applications according to program deadlines (details forthcoming).
-KejuUz4x73dSmIDFQvQ.name: BRDD:BRDD Orientation

-Ki1X3LcQjT0c26AAhvy.description:
Parents and families are invited to attend an optional orientation program September 1 and 2.

  • 8 am – 2 pm: Brunch
    The Met
    Head over to The Met, the main dining location at RISD, located at 30 Waterman Street. Please bring your RISD ID and Orientation nametag in order to enter.
  • 8 am – 2 pm: Move In/Orientation Check-In
    upper quad
    Welcome to New Student Orientation! Time to check in, pick up your RISD ID card and move into your new home (if you haven't done so already). Commuter & Transfer Students: Even if you are not living on campus, be sure to check in, say hello and gather your Orientation materials!
  • 8 am – 2 pm: Information Center
    upper quad
    If you have questions and want to connect with a staff member, visit us in the upper quad at the Information Center.
  • 9 am – 2 pm: Immunization Clinic
    The Met A
    The Wellness Company will be providing immunizations for students who signed up for immunization using the web link sent to your RISD email by Health Services. If you did not sign up, see a health services staff member for more information.
  • 10 am – 2 pm: Resource Fair
    20 Washington Place Auditorium
    Offices across campus are dedicated to supporting you and providing you with the resources you need to be healthy, happy and successful. Visit our many tables at the fair to learn about the important resources you'll have access to throughout your time at RISD.
  • 2:30 – 3 pm: Welcome and President's Address
    First Baptist Church
    Receive your first official welcome to the college. (Families are welcome to attend.)
  • 3 – 3:30 pm: New Student/Family Send-Off Snacks
    First Baptist Church Lawn (rain location 20 Washington Place)
    Enjoy some light send-off snacks before saying goodbye to parents and families.
  • 3:30 – 5 pm: Meetings with Orientation Leaders
    various locations
    Get ready to start your RISD adventure! You'll meet with your Orientation Leader, go over the week’s events and get to know your fellow students.
  • 5 – 6 pm: Dinner
    The Met
    Enjoy dinner at The Met with your Orientation Leaders and small group.
  • 7:30 – 8:30 pm: Residence Hall Meetings
    residence halls
    After spending time with your Orientation Groups, get to know your neighbors and peers in your Residence Hall by attending a floor or building meeting.
  • 9 – 11 pm: First Night Celebration
    upper quad
    Celebrate the first night of New Student Orientation at the upper quad. We'll have an inflatable obstacle course, giant games, food, music and more. Come early and receive a raffle ticket to enter the Cash Cube to catch as many RISDBucks as you can!
-Ki1X3LcQjT0c26AAhvy.name: New Student Orientation Schedule:New Student Orientation Day 1—Sunday

-Ki1tcP0suEUSBxuhQQf.description:
Parents and families are invited to attend an optional orientation program from August 28–30.

  • 8 am – 2 pm: Move in and check in
    upper Quad
    Welcome to RISD. Pick up your ID card and check-in for International Orientation in the upper quad. Make sure to check-in at the immigration table with your documents. There will be plenty of time to settle in, once you have checked in.
  • 7:30 am – 2 pm: Brunch
    The Met
    Head over to The Met, the main dining location at RISD, located at 30 Waterman Street. Bring your RISD ID and Orientation nametag in order to enter.
  • 10 am – 2 pm: Banks and phones
    The Met A
    Let us help you get set up a new bank and phone service. Representatives will be on campus during this time to meet with you.
  • 10 am – 2 pm: Shopping shuttles
    30 Waterman Street
    If you need to shop for your room or apartment, please take advantage of our complimentary shopping shuttles. Vehicles will be running from 30 Waterman to the Seekonk Shopping Area and Providence Place Mall. Bed, Bath & Beyond, Walmart, Target, HomeGoods, TJ Maxx and Home Depot are some stores that may interest you along this route.
  • 10 am – 2 pm: Yard sale
    The Met C
    Stop by our yard sale and claim something for your room or apartment. All items are free.
  • 4:30 – 5 pm: Welcome and President's Address
    RISD Auditorium
    Receive your first official welcome to the college.
  • 5 – 6:30 pm: Dinner/Meet your Orientation Leaders
    The Met
    Meet your Orientation Leaders and the other new students in your Orientation Group. You will be spending the next few days together as you move through the Orientation schedule.
  • 7 – 9 pm: Creating Community Game Night
    20 Washington Place Auditorium
    Join us for a night of desserts, games and fun while getting to your know RISD international community and your Orientation Leaders.
-Ki1tcP0suEUSBxuhQQf.name: International Orientation Schedule:International Student Orientation Day 1—Wednesday

-Ki5VFnAbnMxr74U0uPp.description:
• 8 – 9 am: Breakfast
    The Met
    Grab some breakfast in The Met! Be sure to leave yourself enough time to enjoy your meal before the Orientation sessions start. Meet up with your Orientation Leader by 8:45, so you can walk to the first session with your group.
  • 9 am – 12 pm: Student Affairs at RISD
    RISD Auditorium
    During this session you will have the chance to learn about the many offices on campus that help support your co-curricular experience through programming and services that reflect values of community, inclusiveness, responsibility, leadership and wellbeing.
  • 12 – 1 pm: Lunch
    The Met
    Time to re-fuel. Stop by The Met with your RISD ID and your Orientation nametag for some lunch.
  • 1 – 3 pm: Campus Tours
    campus
    Explore RISD’s urban campus with your Orientation Group. Your Orientation Leaders will guide the way.
  • 3 – 3:30 pm: Public Safety at RISD
    RISD Auditorium
    Whether you are navigating the RISD community or the Providence community, this session will highlight ways to stay safe and informed.
  • 3:30 – 5:30 pm: Consent/Relationships
    RISD Auditorium
    This session will help students understand key components around consent, communication, decision- making, sexual health and relationships.
  • 5:30 – 6:30 pm: Dinner
    The Met
    Dinner time. Gather with your Orientation Group, unwind after a busy day and get excited about the nighttime activity options.
  • 8 – 10 pm: Evening Activities
    upper quad, The Met A and C
    Choose from any of our three night time activities, or visit them all! 1) Bingo: Test your luck at RISD Bingo. Come hang out and get to know other students while you play bingo. There is a chance to win prizes, including gift cards, RISD swag, and more. Find this in Met Room C. 2) Potted Plant Decorating: Decorate a flowerpot, complete with a plant, to bring to your new home, all while relaxing and getting to know other RISD students. Find this in Met Room A. 3) Upper Quad Dance: Show us your best dance moves, or just stop by to enjoy the music. We'll be playing your favorite songs until 10pm at the upper quad. Snacks included.
-Ki5VFnAbnMxr74U0uPp.name: New Student Orientation Schedule:New Student Orientation Day 2—Monday

-Ki5WztLixn3znYI9QfU.description:
• 8 – 9 am: Breakfast
    The Met
    Grab some breakfast in The Met. Be sure to leave yourself enough time to enjoy your meal before the Orientation sessions start.
  • 9:30 – 10 am: Orientation Leader Small Groups
    various locations
    Meet up with your Orientation Leaders and group and head over to Convocation together.
  • 10 – 11 am: Fall Convocation
    RISD Auditorium
    Join President Rosanne Somerson, Provost Kleinman, academic deans, department heads, new faculty members and others for the official opening of the academic year.
  • 11 am – 12:30 pm: Experimental and Foundation Studies (EFS) and Liberal Arts Info Session
    RISD Auditorium
    Your first day of classes is right around the corner. This session overviews important information about your first-year academics, including what to expect and what is expected of you. Joanne Stryker, Dean of Experimental and Foundation Studies (EFS), and Damian White, Dean of Liberal Arts, will lead this session.
  • 12:30 – 1:45 pm: Lunch
    The Met
    Time to re-fuel. Stop by The Met between with your RISD ID and your Orientation name tag for some lunch.
  • 2:30 – 4:30 pm: Building Capacity for Greater Inclusion: Jamie Washington
    RISD Auditorium
    A     defining moment when we start our journey together. This event gives you permission to be curious and to explore our similarities and our differences. Renowned writer and speaker Jamie Washington will facilitate this session to help you explore our full human and artistic potential by engaging both you and your closest educators in the RISD community.
  • 4:30 – 5:00 pm: Orientation Leader Small Groups
    various locations
    Use this time to un-pack the day with your group and Orientation Leaders.
  • 5 – 6 pm: Dinner
    The Met
    Gather with your Orientation Group, unwind after a busy day and get excited about our nighttime activity.
  • 7:30 – 9:30 pm: Night at the Museum
    RISD Museum
    Enjoy one of RISD’s most valuable resources: draw in the galleries, chat with RISD students about their artistic practice, take part in a student-led gallery tour, explore the collection on your own and mingle with friends over snacks in the Grand Gallery. Enter the RISD Museum through the Benefit Street entrance.
-Ki5WztLixn3znYI9QfU.name: New Student Orientation Schedule:New Student Orientation Day 3—Tuesday

-Ki5_P1fd94pTHA8iHp9.description:
• 8 – 9 am: Breakfast
    The Met
    Grab some breakfast in The Met. Be sure to leave yourself enough time to enjoy your meal before the Orientation sessions start. Meet up with your Orientation Leader by 8:45 so you can walk to the first session with your group.
  • 9 am – 12 pm: Library Rotations/Small-group time
    Fleet Library/campus
    Join the staff of the Fleet Library for an in-depth look at all the RISD Library has to offer.
  • 12 – 1 pm: Lunch
    The Met
    Stop by The Met with your RISD ID and your Orientation name tag for some lunch.
  • 1 – 2 pm: Student Employment at RISD
    RISD Auditorium
    Planning to work on campus? Come meet with Nelly Hoffens-Vargas, Financial Aid/Student Employment Counselor, to learn about job opportunities and guidelines at RISD.
  • 1 – 5 pm: Taking care of business/free time
    campus
    Take some time for yourself to relax or get work done.
  • 5 – 6:30 pm: Dinner
    The Met
    Gather with your Orientation Group, begin to unwind after a busy day, and get excited about our nighttime activity.
  • 6:30 – 7:30 pm: Being a RISD Student: Panel and Orientation Closing
    RISD Auditorium
    Attend a panel with current RISD students and ask any questions that you still have. Celebrate with us as we reflect on the week with our closing.
  • 7:30 – 10 pm: Lantern Lighting

First-year and transfer students may apply for the Pre-Orientation Service Experience (POSE), an intensive five-day program prior to New Student Orientation that fosters incoming student engagement with the community around campus. This program empowers you to use art and design to make a difference in the world and creates a foundation for your continued involvement in community service during your time at RISD.

Applications are reviewed during a 1-2 week period after the deadline and students will be notified of acceptance shortly thereafter. On average, 65-70% of applicants are accepted to the POSE program.

In order to access the POSE application below, please sign into your RISD gmail account.

-KkGj8z9JuLP5Lab1S4W.description:
Though most incoming students will move in on Monday, September 2, please refer to the Important Dates page for move-in dates associated with participation in POSE, International Orientation and Brown|RISD Dual Degree Pre-Orientation.

Here are some tips for making the move-in process as smooth as possible:

  • Label everything you have with your name, residence hall name and room number
  • Check your RISD email regularly for move-in related updates
  • Keep an eye on the weather forecast (any weather related changes to move-in schedules will be posted here, on this page)
  • Use “2 Waterman Street, Providence, RI 02903” as your GPS destination (you will see color-coded signs as you drive up the hill directing you to your particular Residence Hall)
  • If you experience travel delays due to the weather or other unforeseen circumstance and expect to arrive at RISD later than move-in hours please email us at orientation@risd.edu
  • During move-in hours the following will also be available: shopping shuttles, immigration check-in, free goods from RISD Flips and vendors for banking and cell phone needs
  • Residence Life staff will be available if you need assistance on move-in day (you can call us at 401 454-6650)
  • Our Information Center will be located on the first floor of Carr House at 210 Benefit Street
  • If you have any questions before you arrive, please email us at orientation@risd.edu
-KkGj8z9JuLP5Lab1S4W.name: Moving day tips

All incoming first-year, transfer and BRDD students attend New Student Orientation. -Kjt8g7rh1_NMBU1fmYW.description:
Prior to the beginning of the fall semester, first-year BRDD students will move into their first-year residence hall at RISD. They will attend a special Dual Degree pre-orientation organized jointly by RISD and Brown and then choose a pre-orientation program to attend (Brown International Student Orientation, Brown Third World Transition Program, RISD POSE or RISD Project Thrive) before the start of the RISD and Brown Orientations.

First-Year BRDD students largely prioritize RISD Orientation, as they will be residents at RISD. Students are invited to participate in first-year group activities at Brown during Orientation and throughout the year. Additionally, students will participate in Brown’s First Reading Seminar Program and in Brown's first-year advising meeting. If you're enrolled in the Dual Degree program and have questions about Pre-Orientation, please email Michele Zager, Assistant Director and Academic Advisor, Brown|RISD Dual Degree Program.

View the BRDD Orientation schedule.
-Kjt8g7rh1_NMBU1fmYW.name: Brown | RISD Dual Degree Orientation — August 25-27

supporting_content.description:
1. After you pay your enrollment deposit in the portal you will be able to access several forms that need to be downloaded, printed, filled-out and then uploaded back into the portal:

    • Declaration of Finances form
    • Bank statement(s) in English (indicating at least one years’ worth of tuition)
    • I-20 application form
    • Copy of passport
  2. Admissions team will then review your uploaded forms. If everything is complete and accurate the office will create, sign and ship your I-20 form to your home. (You will be responsible for paying a SEVIS fee for the processing of the form.)
  3. After receiving your I-20 form from RISD you can then schedule your visa interview. You should review the instructions on the website for the US embassy or consulate where you will be interviewing and you will need to bring the following with you to the interview:

    • I-20 form
    • Declaration of Finances form
    • receipt of payment for the SEVIS fee
    • copy of DS-160
    • receipt of visa application payment
    • passport
    • proof of funding
    • acceptance letter
    • scholarship award letter (if applicable)
  4. When you travel to the United States you should bring the following (note: these forms need to be easily accessed at the airport to share with immigration officials):

    • passport (this will be stamped by a customs official upon arrival in the United States)
    • F-1 student visa
    • original I-20 form (3 pages)
    • copy of the Declaration of Finances form
  5. When you arrive at RISD for move-in day please provide the following to OISS so that the office can activate and register you in SEVIS:

    • passport
    • F-1 student visa
    • I-20 form
    • I-94 arrival/departure record
supporting_content.title: Immigration process

supporting_content.description: Student Financial Services supports your family in seeking, obtaining and making the best use of all resources available to help finance the costs of attending RISD. Students can view charges, review financial aid and schedule payments through the Student Accounts Center at risd.afford.com. They can also provide access to authorized users that will allow them to view their account. Once granted access, authorized users will receive monthly reminders to review the account in addition to important billing reminders. For more on financial services, please review our tuition and aid information.

supporting_content.description: RISD’s 2019–20 tuition is $51,800 for both undergrads and graduate students, with a student activities fee of $260 and an academic and technology fee of $800. The cost of attendance (COA) for any college is based on tuition and required fees (costs that are billed to you directly) plus estimated costs for room and/or rent, board and/or food, supplies, personal expenses and transportation (indirect, variable costs). RISD’s 2019/20 COA for undergraduate students is $72,780. The 2020/21 COA for undergraduates will be released in early spring.
supporting_content.title: Total costs

supporting_content.description: Our team takes care of the billing and collection of tuition, fees, room, board and other charges on your student account, assists students and families with their financial aid and manages student employment on campus. We’re eager to help you and your family with any questions you may have.
supporting_content.title: We can help

-LtfkWUoimNOYBpexUjj.description: We offer health and wellness services to help you build proactive, lifelong approaches to staying well. Our Disability Support Services assist students who have cognitive (learning), psychological and physical disabilities.
-LtfkWUoimNOYBpexUjj.name: Health and wellness

supporting_content.description:
RISD's Health Center offers basic health care (first aid and non-emergency care), gynecologic care, LGBTQ-specific health services, wellness services (physical exams, lab work, nutrition counseling, etc.), STD testing and medical referrals.

Counseling and Psychological Services at RISD provides counseling, crisis and referral services as well as tools, resources and support fo faculty, staff and families to help further awareness and understanding around mental health issues.
supporting_content.title: Health and wellness services

supporting_content.description:
In order to receive accommodations, students need to register with Disability Support Services. Keep in mind that accommodations may take time to arrange, some up to 2–4 weeks, so be sure to make your formal accommodation requests as early as possible, prior to the beginning of the semester. Housing accommodations also need to be registered through RISD Housing.

Disability Support Services offers time management workshops that are open to all RISD students. One-on-one time management coaching is available to students registered with Disability Support Services.
supporting_content.title: Disability support services

supporting_content.description:
As an incoming student, you'll need to complete the following before the start of classes:

  • Share your medical history with RISD and arrange for health insurance coverage
  • Talk to your parents about their future level of involvement in your medical care
  • Get required immunizations
  • Plan ahead for special health care needs
  • Communicate your need for disability services

The Health and Wellness site provides more details about how to complete these steps.
supporting_content.title: Before you arrive

supporting_content.description:
Remember to pack the following for your move to campus:

  • All medications (if applicable) and a plan for how you will get refills (there are a number of pharmacies in the area, but most students use the CVS at nearby Providence Place Mall)
  • Wallet-sized list or phone note of medical history, medications, primary care physician and specialists names
  • Health insurance card if using home health insurance (students using RISD Student Health Insurance Plan will get insurance information within the first week)
  • A small first aid kid including bandaids, thermometer, and any over-the-counter medications you might need
supporting_content.title: What to bring

supporting_content.description: As a vital part of a student’s wellness support system, we value the role you'll continue to play in their health and success. It's important to note that while at RISD, your student will be afforded the benefits of confidential health care. Under Rhode Island privacy laws and federal HIPPA regulations, all students health records are confidential and cannot be discussed without clear documented permission from the student, except in serious circumstances.
supporting_content.title: Info for parents and family

-LtfkrgQpebj0cyix0kB.description: In your first year at RISD, you don't need to worry about signing up for classes—everyone is pre-enrolled in the Experimental and Foundation Studies (EFS) program. Any credits you'd like to transfer should be submitted for review and may count toward liberal arts courses required after your first year.
-LtfkrgQpebj0cyix0kB.name: First-year curriculum

supporting_content.description: You’ll take three studio classes—Drawing, Design and Spatial Dynamics—and two introductory liberal arts classes per semester. Each studio class meets one full day per week, with students expected to work on an ongoing series of assignments outside of class time.
supporting_content.title: First year at a glance

supporting_content.description:
All first-year students will be issued a tool box when they arrive. It includes the following: 16' metric/inch tape measure, 6 3/4" coping saw, 6-1/2" coping saw blade, 8" slip joint pliers, 8" long nose pliers, 7" diagonal pliers, 6-way screwdriver, 12" combination square, drill bit set, 16oz claw hammer, Olfa BN-l knife, Olfa LB-5B blades, Ryoba compact saw, dust mask, safety glasses.

Some professors have specific lists that they will send out a few weeks before classes start and others will inform students of supply requirements in class. Generally, these supplies and materials are available on or near campus.

You're encouraged bring supplies and materials you already own to use in your work. These might include: portfolio, sketch book, charcoal sticks, charcoal pencils, staple gun, brushes, markers, Conte crayons, erasers, newsprint pad, rubber cement, glue, fixative, masking tape, pencil sharpener, mat knife, push pins, scissors, metal clamps, woodcarving tools, large metal ruler. (Feel free to include other things and do not feel like you must bring everything listed above.)
supporting_content.title: EFS supplies

supporting_content.description: RISD assesses AP, IB, A Levels and college credits that might count toward liberal arts credits. Please note that required liberal arts classes cannot be waived, so any credits granted go toward additional liberal arts classes needed to graduate. The AP Board automatically sends scores, but students must request IB scores and A Levels must request be sent to the Liberal Arts office. College coursework should be sent to Admissions in the form of official transcripts.
supporting_content.title: Transferring credits

-Lydj-4evdBpLUZ_di_X.name: BRDD curriculum

supporting_content.description:
The BRDD program is a five year program in which students develop and integrate diverse spheres of academic and artistic interests. Students will choose a concentration at Brown and a major at RISD and receive a Bachelor of Arts (A.B.) degree or, with careful planning, a Bachelor of Science (Sc.B.) from Brown and a Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) degree from RISD.

The five-year plans needed to complete the BRDD program are highly individualized and must be co-created between the student and their RISD Department Head, Brown Concentration Advisor, and the BRDD Advisor to accomplish degree requirements and the student's specific goals.
supporting_content.title: Degrees

supporting_content.description: Students are expected to finish both degrees within the allotted five years, or ten (fall/spring) semesters, of the program. Students in the program must complete at least 156 credit hours. Of those, at least 60 credit hours (15 course credits) must be taken at Brown during a fall/spring term. Courses taken at Brown during a summer session, credits earned through a study abroad program, and shared credits from RISD do not count towards this requirement. In addition, students must complete curricular requirements at Brown, curricular requirements at RISD, and a Capstone requirement specific to the program. The Brown | RISD Dual Degree Program site provides a clear breakdown of Brown and RISD curricular requirements.
supporting_content.title: Requirements from each school

supporting_content.description:
Upon acceptance to the program after completion of secondary school, students will undertake a first year of Experimental and Foundation Studies at RISD and no more than three courses at Brown, including a First Year Seminar during their first semester.

During the first year, students live on RISD’s campus and follow this schedule:

  • Fall: Drawing Studio; Design Studio; Spatial Dynamics (3D) Studio; Theory and History of Art and Design (H101); First-Year Seminar at Brown
  • Winter Session: RISD Elective
  • Spring: Drawing Studio; Design Studio; Spatial Dynamics (3D) Studio; RISD Liberal Arts or Brown Course; RISD Liberal Arts or Brown Course
supporting_content.title: First year schedule

-L5yRc0mJmfK1W24E3vp.description:
Unless required to participate in the RISD Laptop Program, students should follow the Brown computer purchase policy.

RISD's Information Technology Services

Information Technology Services (ITS) partners with members of the RISD community to power creativity by contributing valuable technical services and solutions. As a student you'll use various information technologies on campus including email, the Housing Portal, Student Planning (registration) and WebAdvisor (grades).

ITS Service Desk

RISD’s ITS Service Desk is the community’s first point of contact to request or inquire about information technology services and support. The Service Desk provides responsive technical support to the RISD community.

Activating your network account

RISD will activate a network account that will provide you with a single user name and password to access a wide variety of RISD resources and support including access to email, network storage and WebAdvisor (student information). Check your personal email to obtain your RISD Account username and password.

Buying a computer

Open-access and department-specific computer labs are available for student use throughout campus. However, most students find that having their own computer is more convenient than relying on departmental and open-access lab computers. Before purchasing a computer please review the minimum requirements.

Laptop Program

The following academic majors require students to have department-specific laptop hardware and software tools used extensively within the departmental curriculum:

  • Architecture
  • Furniture Design
  • Graphic Design
  • Industrial Design
  • Interior Architecture
  • Photography
-L5yRc0mJmfK1W24E3vp.name: BRDD:Connect with campus technology

-L5yRxdDdkMdddG4zkVh.description:
Brown|RISD Dual Degree students are required to be on RISD’s Foundation meal plan and will automatically have 70 dining points on their Brown ID card to spend at Brown dining facilities.

RISD's Foundation plan provides unlimited meal swipes to The Met. Located in the primary residential quad, it is the largest dining hall on campus, with menus that change daily and offer a wide selection of freshly prepared items—including traditional, vegetarian and vegan options. Students also appreciate The Met’s grill, artisan pizza oven, salad bar and deli, along with freshly made desserts and house-made sushi.

On the Foundation plan students may choose to use one meal swipe per day at any of the following locations:

For a more bistro-style experience, Portfolio Café (adjacent to the Fleet Library at 15 West) is a great place to meet friends and dine on varied and ethnically inspired cuisine.

Watermark Café (conveniently located in the risd:store) offers an intimate setting for fresh salads, smoothies, burritos, specialty beverages and other items made from local ingredients.

Located near the homes for Architecture, Landscape Architecture and Industrial Design on South Main Street, Jolly Roger Deli features gourmet sandwiches.

Carr Haus Café, a centrally located student-run café, serves coffee and snacks.

Café Pearl, located in the RISD Museum, is a beautiful location serving coffee and snacks (though it does not accept meal plans or risdbucks).

They may also purchase items using their dining points. Students on the Foundation plan receive a total of $500 dining points per year. Other benefits include 6 guest meals per year (3 per semester), two free exchangeable to-go (Ozzi) containers per year, and a complimentary celebration cake for birthdays or other celebrations.

If you have any questions, RISD Dining + Catering can be reached at 401 454-6360.
-L5yRxdDdkMdddG4zkVh.name: BRDD:Dining plans and information

-L5yjlmHTVnjvl4A2VaY.description: Applicants to the Dual Degree Program must submit financial aid applications to both the RISD Student Financial Services Office and Brown University Financial Aid and follow the guidelines provided on each institution’s website. Given that students will be admitted through procedures in place at both institutions, financial aid will be made with respect to formulas operating at both. Should a student be rejected as a Dual Degree student, or choose to attend only one of the two institutions, he or she will receive the financial aid package offered by that institution. Financial aid for students admitted into the Dual Degree Program will be calculated according to the Brown formula.
-L5yjlmHTVnjvl4A2VaY.name: BRDD:Finance your education

-L5ymZOzV6PWqZDMeGw7.description:
The following information is provided as a resource to guide your considerations about financing your education.

Estimated cost of attendance

RISD’s 2019–20 tuition is $51,800 for both undergrads and graduate students, with a student activities fee of $260 and an academic and technology fee of $800. The cost of attendance for any college is based on tuition and required fees (costs that are billed to you directly) plus estimated costs for room and/or rent, board and/or food, supplies, personal expenses and transportation (indirect, variable costs). RISD’s 2019–20 COA for undergraduate students is $72,780. You'll find more detailed information on RISD's main website.

Applying for financial aid

In order to determine eligibility for any type of financial aid, first-year applicants must complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and Profile application. You'll find more detailed information about deadlines and requirements on RISD's main website.

If you have any questions about financing your education, Student Financial Services can be reached at 401 454-6661 or sfs@risd.edu.
-L5ymZOzV6PWqZDMeGw7.name: Early Decision, First-year and Transfer:Finance your education

-L7ArSad8l6Fg8P4BidX.description:
For those students living on campus, RISD mailbox numbers will be sent to incoming students by email in the second week of July. Please wait until you receive your mailbox to ship your items to RISD. Download the shipping label PDF and follow the instructions below:

  • ONE LABEL PER BOX/CARTON
  • PLACE LABEL ON TOP OF CARTON TOWARD THE LOWER RIGHT CORNER.
  • TAPE OVER LABEL WITH CLEAR PLASTIC TAPE.
  • USE NEW BOXES ONLY, BOXES SHOULD NOT BE CRUSHED, TORN, OR OTHERWISE DAMAGED.

We recommend:

  • Ship clothes, books, non-breakable items.
  • Electronics, computers, stereos be brought with the student to minimize cost and potential damage if not packed properly.
  • Boxes be no larger than 24”x24”x24”, the size of a small end table, and weigh no more than 70 lbs.
  • TV’s, refrigerators, microwaves can be purchased locally and will be more cost effective than if packaged and shipped from home.
  • Ship via UPS to ensure tracking capability and adequate insurance coverage. BRING SHIPPING RECEIPTS WITH YOU. If boxes are lost, we can help you track them down with this information.
  • THE UPS STORE can help you package and/or ship your belongings.

To find the nearest THE UPS STORE to you, call 1-800-789-4623 or check the web at www.theupsstore.com.
-L7ArSad8l6Fg8P4BidX.name: Shipping to RISD

-L7AscWpNYM3GdRspKV0.description:
Though most incoming students will move in on Sunday, September 1, please refer to the Enrollment and beyond page for move-in dates associated with participation in POSE, International Orientation and Brown|RISD Dual Degree Pre-Orientation.

Here are some tips for making the move-in process as smooth as possible:

  • Label everything you have with your name, residence hall name and room number
  • Check your RISD email regularly for move-in related updates
  • Keep an eye on the weather forecast (any weather-related changes to move-in schedules will be posted on this page)
  • Use “2 Waterman Street, Providence, RI 02903” as your GPS destination (you will see color-coded signs as you drive up the hill directing you to your particular residence hall)
  • If you experience travel delays due to the weather or other unforeseen circumstances and expect to arrive at RISD later than move-in hours, please email us at orientation@risd.edu
  • On move-in day, representatives from various departments across campus will be present at a resource fair to share information and answer any questions
  • Residence Life staff will be available if you need assistance on move-in day (you can also call us at 401 454-6650)
  • If you have any questions before you arrive, please email us at orientation@risd.edu
-L7AscWpNYM3GdRspKV0.name: Moving day tips

-LAUVT3UzyeDyqfRz8O_.description:
Most transfer students are required to attend the Summer EFS program, a six-week immersion in RISD’s approach to studio learning. The program is taught by EFS faculty and offers the same three studios as in the foundation year: Drawing, Design and Spatial Dynamics. Each studio session meets 10 hours (over one and a half days) a week—or a total of 60 hours per course.

Students who complete the program successfully earn nine of the 18 required credits in EFS and find it to be an excellent way to transition to RISD. It both strengthens their confidence as makers and reinforces critical thinking and making capabilities. You can find important dates related to transfer students, including the dates of Summer EFS, below.

-LFIOEOApCPkAro4IBX2.description:
If your student is coming to RISD from overseas and you have questions about visa and travel, please be sure to review our information for international students by following the link below.



1. Incoming international students get access to their international forms in their portal once they pay their deposit. They need to download, print, and fill out the following, then upload them back into their portal:


2. Once a student fills out / uploads these documents, the Admissions office looks them over for errors, and, if all looks good, creates, signs, and ships the student’s I-20 to their home abroad. Students can then schedule their visa interview. They also need to pay a fee to SEVIS, the government site we use to create I-20s. 3. At their visa interview, students need: their I-20, Declaration of Finances form, receipt of payment for the SEVIS fee, copy of DS-160, receipt of visa application payment, passport, proof of funding, acceptance letter, and (if applicable) scholarship award letter. Students should review the instructions on the website for the US Embassy or Consulate where they will be interviewing.


4. When traveling to the USA, students should carry their passport, F-1 student visa, original I-20 form (all 3 pages), and a copy of the Declaration of Finances form. Upon arrival to the U.S., the Customs Official will stamp the student’s passport.


5. Upon arrival to RISD, students should bring their passport, visa, I-20 and I-94 arrival/departure record to OISS, where a staff member will activate and register the student in SEVIS.

Students should plan to turn in their international documents in a timely manner, because wait times really vary depending on the consulate they visit to have their visa interview. We don't have a hard deadline for turning in the documents, but ideally the student should have them in by early June.
-LFIOEOApCPkAro4IBX2.name: Info for international families
